title.narrative: 4KEN10401: Access to Clean Energy Services in Kenya

description.narrative: Access to Clean and Sustainable Energy Services in Kenya
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Number of additional males benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of additional females benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of men above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Number of women above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Total number of people above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste

The overall purpose of this programme is to support Kenya Government to enhance access to clean and sustainable energy services while supporting its environmental management for accelerated economic growth.

comment.narrative: 1. SE4All AA and IP not available in Kenya 2. 0 3. No report available on biomass cook stoves testing 4. Economic and technical viability of bioethanol for cooking is not tested in Kenya

description.narrative: 4KEN10405: Mainstreaming Sustainable Land Management in Agropastoral production Systems of Kenya

participating-org.narrative: UN DEPT OF ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL AFFAIRS
FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE

title.narrative: INTERNATIONAL INDIVIDUAL CONSULTANT TO UNDERTAKE A TERMINAL EVALUATION OF THE MAINSTREAMING SUSTAINABLE LAND MANAGEMENT IN AGRO-PASTORAL PRODUCTION SYSTEMS OF KENYA PROJECT (SLM)

description.narrative: Sustainable Land Management providing the basis for economic development, food security and sustainable livelihoods while restoring the ecological integrity of the arid and semi arid lands.

participating-org.narrative: UN DEPT OF ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL AFFAIRS
FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE

description.narrative: populated place
facility center
seat of a first-order administrative division
second-order administrative division

provider-org.narrative: FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE
FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE
FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE
FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE
FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE

description.narrative: 1. % of the rangeland registering improvement in rangeland condition in pilot districts (using range condition measurements) 2. % of land users with skills in improved land management 3. % of cultivators in the pilot landscapes adopting 3-5 forms of improved cultivation practices
To provide land users and managers with the enabling policy institutional and capacity environment for effective adoption of SLM in the agropastoral production system
Carbon mitigated from sustainable charcoaling

comment.narrative: Currently no sustainable charcoaling no carbon mitigated from it
At least half a million tons of carbon dioxide mitigated from sustainable charcoal in the districts by midterm and a million cumulative at the end of the project

The project has continued to supported adoption of energy efficient technologies in the pilot districts In Narok FFS members in Ewaso Ngiro Suswa and Mulot over 300 farmers were trained on the use of the maendeleo jiko cooking stoves A total 350 jikos were given to the trainees as a part of promoting energy efficient technologies in the district The adoption and use of the jikos will reduce deforestation since less fuel wood is required In Mbeere North 200 rocket stoves were procured for the new FFS and one institutional jiko constructed at St Michael Gacuriri Primary school and a charcoal kiln constructed at Kune In Dadaab 400 energy efficient cooking stoves were bought and distributed to FFS and community members In Kyuso a total of 105 maendeleo jikos cooking stoves were distributed to Muunda Mweu Faith Youth and Makkki FFS The project also supported establishment of three 3 charcoal kilns at Mitamisyi Ngomeni and Kamusiliu The established kilns have better carbonization control and hence higher yield of better quality charcoal

description.narrative: Improvement in food security

comment.narrative: Various statistics indicate that over 65 of people in ASAL depend in part on food aid and face substantive food insecurity

Level of dependency on food aid in target landscapes reduced by at least 30
Number of food secure days increased by at least 40 for more than 50 of the population in the target landscapes

In the reporting period the project has supported improvement of local livestock breeds for purposes of increasing productivity and resilience against diseases In Narok upgrading of livestock was undertaken where 30 dorper breeding rams 10 galla goats and 60 kenbro cockerels and 100 langstroth and Kenya Top Bar hives were bought and distributed to farmer field schools and community members to boost upgrading of local breeds In Kyuso 528 Galla breeding goats 610 poultry birds and 115 langstroth bee hives were bought and distributed to the community In Mbeere North 66 galla goats 52 dairy goats and 300 1 month old rainbow rooster chicks and 100 langstroth bee hives were distributed to communities In Dadaab 32 dairy goats 80 kurchi birds and 20 langstroth bee hives were bought and distributed to farmer field schools
To enhance agricultural productivity in the pilot districts the project also provided various drought resistant crops to FFS and the local communities In Dadaab a total of 720 kg of cow peas K20KUU27 1840 kg of greengrams N26 1840kg maize DHO2 and 30kg of watermelon seeds were distributed to FFS Mbeere North district distributed to the community and FFS a total of 752Kg of cowpeas M66 308kg of maize KCB 645kg of greengrams N26 520 kgs of Sorghum Gardam 192kgs of finger millet 380kgs of beans 158kgs of Dolichos In Kyuso the project bought and distributed 300 Kgs Dolichos 300 Kgs Cow peas K80 200 kgs KVU271 440kgs Pearl Millet 490Kgs 1230 Kgs Green grams N26 and 880 Kgs Gadam Sorghum to FFS farmers to plant In Narok North 87 farmers from 2 Farmer Field Schools namely Ilaretok Orkilenyae FFS were trained on drought tolerantresistant crops and best agropastoral practices while 45 farmers from Salbet and Omomet FFS were trained on water harvesting fruit tree establishment The two FFS were also trained on mulching and manure The project also linked farmer field schools in Mulot with African Agricultural Technology Foundation who trained 62 farmers on drought Tego Maize which is a type of maize resistant to drought
Food security enhancement has been realized as reported through statistics of community members who have been removed from relief food dependencyregisters due to attaining self sufficiency in household food needs and increased incomes A combination of supporting interventions have led to this favorable situation continuous capacity building of FFS members on good agricultural practices adoption of climate smart agriculture by the concerned communities support in improved livestock breeds which have on average increased milk output

description.narrative: Improvement in rangeland condition

comment.narrative: Various statistics report that about 80 of rangelands badly degraded
At least 25 of the rangeland registering improvement in rangeland condition in pilot districts using range condition measurements by midterm and 50 cumulative by end of the project

This indicator is still on target All the four pilot project areas Mbeere North Kyuso Narok North and Dadaab have continued implementing measures aimed at rehabilitating communal degraded lands as well as onfarm soil and water conservation interventions This is largely through physical and biological conservation measures instituted at both landscape and farm level and impressive recovery results are evident with about 45 recovery of baseline situation The initiative through KEFRI enabled identification of suitable tree species for the dryland ecosystems and communities have embraced planting them These include species Neem Azidirachta Indica which is doing wonderfully well in Dadaab and has been embraced by schools and individuals due to its multipurpose nature In the field of enabling environment and institutional capacity building the project has partnered with KAPSLM in facilitating CSOs form County platforms which in turn will act as vehicles for the County SLM Strategic Investment Framework CSIF through which lobbying and advocacy for SLM funding could be actualizedThe County governments have been looped in for sustainability of this initiative

description.narrative: Improvement in woodlands condition

comment.narrative: Various statistics report that about 70 of the woodlands are degraded
At least 25 of woodlands showing recovery as measured by regeneration and improvements in species index and canopy cover

Woodland conditions and wood cover improvements are evident in the pilot areas Several suitable tree species identified by KEFRI have been planted by communities and significant survival rates recorded During the reporting period the project implemented various land rehabilitation activities including reseeding of 2172 hectares of degraded lands with pastures in the four pilot districts The Project also distributed 99778 tree seedlings and 14995 fruit trees to communities in Narok Kyuso Dadaab and Mbeere North districts with an aim of increasing tree cover The percentage tree cover in the long run will significantly increase since farmers are well sensitized and trained on agroforestry tree management afforestation and efforts to increase tree planting are supported by FFS group nurseries

description.narrative: Quantity of land managed using SLM principles

comment.narrative: Limited land under SLM no clear documentation on what little is under SLM
At least 70000 ha total 28 sites2500 ha under SLM principles supported by experiential learning

The project is active in an area covering 640000 Ha over which it is making significant contributions towards adoption of SLM practices The Farmer Field Schools FFS are the entry points for SLM technologies A total of 54 FFS with total membership of over 1600 households are practicing landscape rehabilitation efforts and onfarm SLM practices SLM principles in use include addressing the drivers of land degradation reducing land degradation through keeping fewer but highly productive livestock breeds planting trees and drought resistant crop seed varieties practicing climate smart agriculture which involves use of weather information forecasts water harvesting technologies conservation agriculture investing in soil fertility improvement measures that reduce heavy use of biofuels eg improved charcoal kilns and use of energy efficient cookstoves and other ecosystem restoration initiatives

description.narrative: Knowledge based land use planning forms the basis for improving drylands sustainable economic development
Change in soil fertility

comment.narrative: Very low and declining exact levels for pilot districts obtained during inception
At least 30 increase in soil fertility from baselines for land users consistently engaging in 35 improved practices by midterm and by 30 cumulatively by end of the project

Results of soil fertility tests done by KARI were released to the individual farmers each with a recommendation for soil fertility management unique to their own farm Technical staff in the field have been instrumental in deciphering the recommendations to the farmers and guiding them farmers so that they get optimal crop production from their farmsUse of farmyard manure and or commercial fertilizers and growing of nitrogen fixing crop varieties in rotation with other crops are some of the practices farmers are using Use of animalfarmyard manure has been recommended for majority of the farmers on account of improving the water holding capacity of the soils and also aiding in improvement of soil structure

description.narrative: Lessons generated

comment.narrative: Limited knowledge management happening now no clear mechanism for generating and sharing lessons

Lessons on improving land and resource tenure range rehabilitation sustainable charcoaling improving livestock mobility and other important project initiatives available for dissemination through the upscaling project

Lessons generated and knowledge management continues to receive keen attention by all players The ME strategy employs a multilayered system for generation of knowledge dissemination and feedback loops At community level critical and important SLM knowledge is generated and documented at the FFS level jointly by FFS members and their facilitators through AESA Lessons on improving land and resource tenure range rehabilitation sustainable charcoaling crop and livestock improvement aso are generated These lessons are shared among group members and DMT who act as custodians of the same before onward transmission to PMU PMU synthesizes this for UNDP and project board consumption including making news bulletins Other forms of knowledge is covered through field missions by PMUPSC as they engage with the project beneficiaries This is usually captured in back to office reports file notes or technical reports Research bodies and other stakeholders have also been generating knowledge through field trials and demos with FFS groups Such information has been shared at stakeholder workshops and disseminated in form of SLM book The UNDP and SLM websites continue to be credible avenues of disseminating knowledge learnt Regional exchange visit in Arusha Tanzania CSOs workshop in Nakuru and Workshop for the Regional Pastoral Livelihoods Resilience Project are other avenues where sharing of experiences and lessons learnt has taken place The project office has shared the lessons with the parent TerrAfrica SIP Program through a monkey survey conducted on its behalf by a consulting firm

description.narrative: Number of people with relevant skills for SLM

comment.narrative: Less than 15 of land users and pastoralists have skills for improved management less than 50 of technical officers have updated SLM skills

At least 40 of land users and 30 of technical officers requiring to update skills have done so by midterm by the end of project at least 60 of land users and 75 of technical officers cumulatively have updated skills

The target for technical staff training in SLM issues is overwhelmingly high 100 since all staff operating in the pilot districts have had trainings pertaining to SLM These include refresher trainings on soil conservation environmental impact assessment and audit as well as agricultural products value addition The project has also supported exchange tours for farmers in the pilot districts In Mbeere farmers visited Kieni East Njoro Nakuru Kirinyaga and Laikipia The visit enhanced their knowledge on water harvesting for crop and fodder production dairy farming in dry areas pasture production small scale irrigation beekeeping and melia production In Narok FFS members in Mulot and Ewaso Ngiro visited 6 farms belonging to fellow group members In Dadaab 15 PFS members and 6 DMT officer visited Chepareria West pokot The participant gained knowledge on pasture management dry land farming and beekeeping The skills and knowledge so acquired has cascaded down to the communities through FFS facilitators Over 1600 community household members approx12000 persons have benefited from agro ecological systems analysis trainings demonstrated at the FFS Many other community members have been reached through field days exhibitions print and electronic media with an overall 50 of estimated target achieved In addition the project has also supported capacity building of the technical officers from the pilot districts as follows 1 PhD 6 Master degrees 4 diploma and 15 certificates courses

description.narrative: Percentage of land and resource users adopting improved practices

comment.narrative: Less than 20 engaging in 12 improved practices consistently
At least 25 of cultivators in the pilot landscapes adopting 35 forms of improved practices by midterm and 75 cumulatively by project end

This target continues to be exceeded as new FFS are recruited and members trained on various SLM practices Adoption rates are high since training is through demonstrations based on AgroEcological Systems Analysis AESA at the FFS demo plot with individual farmers replicating the learnt practices on their farms The range of improved farming practices include land preparations including suitableappropriate WH technologies for crop productionerection of appropriate soil and water conservation measures fertility improvement initiatives choice of crop seed timely planting based on weather forecasts timely weeding and harvesting managing post harvest losses breed selection and improvement observance of optimal stocking rates etc

description.narrative: Use of weather data for adapting SLM practices

comment.narrative: Less than 5 use of weather information provided by the early warning systems of Kenya Met and Dept of resource mapping and planning

At least 25 of the agriculturalists and pastoralists in the pilot landscapes taking decisions on the basis of the weather and drought early warning information by midterm and 50 cumulatively by project end

The use of weather information for farm decision making has been adopted by more than 60 of FFS community members The uptake of the scientificmodern weather information has been commendable save for the times when forecast falls short of prediction leading to loss of faith by users District Management Team DMT members have been instrumental in relaying this information in conjunction with Kenya Meteorological Department staff working in the pilot Counties and through other stakeholders such as FBOs Community based drought early warning information is disseminated to the pilot communities by National Drought Management Authority again in conjunction with DMT

description.narrative: The policy regulatory and institutional environment support sustainable land management in the agropastoral production system and ASALs
Adoption of improved kilns in carbonization

comment.narrative: Less than 5 use improved kilns in carbonization
Number of charcoal producers using improved kiln in carbonization in pilot landscapes increase by at least 30 by midterm and a cumulative 50 by project end
The baseline target has been surpassed by farThere are now 9 improved kilns in the project pilot areas compared to 5 reported previously representing an increase of 80 during the reporting period

description.narrative: Improvement in local resource governance institutions

comment.narrative: Currently traditional institutions sidelined in natural resource management but formal institutions not effective at local level

By mid project traditional resource institutions in pilot landscapes have assessed the effectiveness of their rules and regulations in modern day resource governance and have identified ways to improve be end of project several agreements entered into with formal institutions for resource governance
The traditional institutions for NRM have continued to play their roles as trained Reduced conflicts over resources have been witnessed courtesy of their timely interventions

description.narrative: Number of functional charcoal associations

comment.narrative: No charcoal associations
At least 5 charcoal associations have rules and regulations for sustainable charcoal and are actively enforcing them

The number of functional charcoal associations remains 5 4 in Mbeere North and 1 in Kyuso Narok has a few broker registered associations which have not been legally functional The associations though trained on new charcoal rules have faced teething problems because charcoal business has not been clearly understoodstreamlined in terms of issuance of permits for production and transportation Existence of brokers has only served to complicate the situation because they brokers produce charcoal in questionable environments

description.narrative: Number of groups with operational sustainable charcoal processes

comment.narrative: No groups engaging in sustainable charcoal
At least 5 groups with sustainable charcoal production operations and earning money from carbon finance

The number of groups with operational sustainable charcoal processes has grown by 80 to 9 from 5 reported previously Mbeere 6 groups and Kyuso 3 groups Efficient charcoaling kilns are gaining acceptance among the pilot communities and are likely to be the technology of choice moving forward This is partly because they use branches instead of whole trees and also because of short time needed for a throughput approx 24 hours

description.narrative: Number of policies mainstreaming SLM

comment.narrative: All policy statements mention importance of SLM but dont have details of how SLM will be ensured
At least 2 policies revised to mainstream SLM principles and so provide a better policy environment for SLM

The support to SLM National platform has been on course The devolved system of governance has necessitated a paradigm shift as most planning and funding of SLM interventions will be at County level SLM in partnership with KAPSLM has rolled out support to establishment of County Strategic Investment Forum CISF This forum will lobby for mainstreaming of SLM interventions at the County level by deliberately planning for such interventions in the CIDPs including budgetary support SLM project has continued participating and facilitating the development of relevant policies such as Camel policy The Project has also supported strengthening of traditional institutions to curb overexploitation of natural resources

description.narrative: Number of policies with legislation and institutional arrangement for effective implementation

comment.narrative: Few SLM policies have updated and effective frameworks well linked into the local institutions

There has been sustained focus on use of stakeholder organizations to bring this target to fruition camel policy has been supported and is almost successful CSOs and CECs have been well sensitized and will serve as the vehicles to spearhead SLM policy formulation at County level Already the Central and South Rift Counties of Nakuru Narok Kericho Kajiado Buret and Baringo have elected officials to coordinate the lobbying and advocacy of SLM issues at County level

description.narrative: Revenue from charcoal going to District and national revenue

comment.narrative: Minimal collection through licensing but none through taxation
Collection of revenue by Districts and Kenya Revenue Authority from charcoal processes increase by 25 by midterm and 50 cumulatively be end of the project
Capturing of revenue streams from the County governments and KRA still remains a challenge owing to unclear trading terms explained earlier in this report

description.narrative: Viability of the agropastoralism production system increased through diversification increased access to finance for SLM
Change in agricultural productivity

comment.narrative: Current low and declining exact levels of selected crops to be obtained during inception
At least 20 increase in agricultural produce for key crops for those adopting 35 improved practices consistently by midterm and 50 cumulative by project end

The increase in productivity is is evident in pilot area locations with significant yields being reported even in times of drought This stems from adoption of good agricultural practices by FFS farming communities The true margin of improvements in farm yield would need a survey Diversification into other livelihoods such as fish farming has taken place Groups have been supported to start income generating activities such as bee keeping and weaving of mats and baskets Access to finances has been achieved through involvement of relevant stakeholders such as banks and micro credit institutions Equity bank has been involved in providing financial literacy to some of the SLM FFS groups and extending credit facilities to willing farmers

description.narrative: Incidents of conflicts over resources inter and intra pastoralists and agriculturalists

comment.narrative: Very high number of incidents of conflicts specific baseline will be obtained during inception
At least 10 reduction in incidents of conflicts over land and resources in the pilot districts and a cumulative 50 reduction by project end

The support given to pastoralists in growing establishing pastures at landscape and individual farms has ensured a fair supply of the same during periods of scarcity This has tremendously reduced pasture related conflicts in the pilot districtsProvision of requisite infrastructure such as water pans and boreholes and training of overseer committees has also ensured communities live in harmony with neighboring communities

description.narrative: Increase in household income

comment.narrative: Over 85 of people live below the UN poverty line living on less than a dollar a day exact household incomes in the pilot landscape will be established during inception
By mid project at least 25 increase in household incomes for more than 40 of participating households cumulatively rising to at least 40 for more than 50 of households

Diversification of farm enterprises continued taking centre stage in improving household incomes Additional households income from fish farming has been introduced in Narok This is aimed at improving both nutrition and incomes for the FFS group members and their families The income generation activities previously reported were given more attention during the period under review ie more drought tolerant crop seeds planted more beehives distributed and apiaries established mores dairy goats and improved chicken reared Generally incomes at household level for FFS beneficiaries have increased by approximately 30 from baseline situation

description.narrative: Increase in livestock trade and prices

comment.narrative: Currently livestock trading riddled with problems of insecurity lack of up to date information on prices and therefore very low prices being obtained
At least a 20 increase in livestock prices being obtained in markets within the pilot landscapes due to better marketingtrading conditions

The project has supported the development of livestock marketing yards and slaughter houses in a bid to improve livestock trade Organized market trading has improved access to markets and livestock numbers and prices increased as brokers are kept at bay Flayers have been trained on processing of hides and skins including marketing and are now fetching better money However insecurity in such areas as Dadaab is eroding the gains made by improving the trading infrastructure

description.narrative: Mobile livestock

comment.narrative: The current trend is tilted to fast rates of sedenterization specific baseline will be obtained during inception
At least 50 of current mobile pastoralists still retain livestock mobility by the end of the project

The project continued to support livestock mobility through peace building meetings along livestock corridors disease surveillance and vaccinations in the pilot district In Mbeere North spot vaccination was conducted for goats against Contagious Caprine Pleuropneumonia and surveillance of diseases along Ishiria Mwingi and Tharaka stock routesThe project has also improved infrastructure in the pilot districts such as livestock sale yards and loading ramps watering points disease control programmes including vet lab services along the routes and dry season grazing areas in crossborder planning This together with the ongoing support to pastoral communities in the pilot sites has hopefully brought a fair percentage of the livestock keepers on productive and sustainable mobility mode

description.narrative: Number of households or individuals accessing micro finance and credits

comment.narrative: Less than 10 of households have access
At least 25 increase in numbers accessing microfinance and credits

The project has continued enhancing community linkages with various microfinance institutions as previously reported Access to credit is within easy reach for farmers but actual acquisition remains low on account of high cost of borrowing most farmers are credit averse banks hesitant to give credit for agricultural ventures in asals on account of high risk of incurring bad debts high default rates owing to frequent crop and livestock failures occasioned by droughts and climate change

description.narrative: The project was designed to consolidate the peace infrastructure process and establish the foundations for a peaceful and successful political transition in Kenya from 2010 to 2013

description.narrative: 1. 3 NAMAs developed 2. Number of climate change frameworks, strategies and policies developed

comment.narrative: 1. No NAMAs developed 2. 1 climate change framework (climate change response strategy) developed
GHG inventory in place 4 NAMAs developed Climate change law
GHG inventory being developed 3 NAMAs developed (waste, Cooking stoves and Charcoal) Climate change Act 2016 enacted Paris Agreement Ratified by Kenya
GHG inventory in place 4 NAMAs implemented Climate Change Policies in place
GHG inventory still being developed 4 NAMAs (none was funded by the NAMA Facility - fundraising in progress) Climate Finance Policy approved by Cabinet

description.narrative: This is a Management Project designed with the aim of ensuring Development Effectiveness.
The project is meant to contribute to Country Office operations management efficiency and effectiveness is improved through administrative support services and security.

Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Number of additional males benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of additional females benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste

The project will address biodiversity conservation and sustainable land management in Kenya.

Proportion of supported counties that have capacity to formulate laws that promote devolution 2. Number of supported counties with functional performance management systems 3. Phase 2: Integrated Project (2014-2018) 1. 75% 2. 13 3. 15 4. 6 5. 3 -Planning; 3-Budgeting; 3 -M&E

Presidential election voter turn out 7. Proportion of spoilt votes

comment.narrative: 1. 3 legislations (Political Parties Amendment Act 2016, Election Laws Amendment Act 2016 and Elections Offences Act 2016) enacted. 2. 13 (13 policies, procedures and systems of IEBC and ORPP strengthened) 3. 15,850,899 (29 and 33 additional voters registered during Mombasa and Nyeri ASK Shows respectively) 4. 48.3% 5. 0% 6. 0% 7. 0%
1. 4 (Qualifications and requirements for candidates; Presidential Petition Rules; Election Petition Rules; PP nomination rules) 2. 1 3. 19,850,899 4. 48% 5. 100% 6. 80% 7. 2%
